required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Prevalence of Diastasis m. Rectus Abdominis in Postpartum Women
clinical_study.official_title: Prevalence of Diastasis m. Rectus Abdominis and the Relationship Between Diastasis and Pelvic Floor Muscle Dysfunction in Postpartum Women

brief_summary.textblock:
This study will evaluate the prevalence of diastasis m. rectus abdominis after delivery.
And relations between diastasis of m. rectus abdominis and pelvic floor muscle dysfunction in woman after delivery.

detailed_description.textblock: Evaluation of the width of the album lineage within the evaluation of diastasis of the rectus abdominis by 2D and 3D USG with evaluation, relation to pelvic floor dysfunctions, such as pain, urinary incontinence and prolapse, by evaluating pelvic floor muscle tone, pelvic floor muscle strength and endurance, and urethral hypermobility.

primary_outcome.measure: Detection of the prevalence of diastasis of the rectus abdominis in postpartum women.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Six weeks to up to 6 months after birth
primary_outcome.description: IRD distance measured by a linear probe 2D usg, 4.5 cm above the navel, 4.5 cm below the navel. At rest, with maximum inhaling and exhaling, when raising the torso and when raising the lower limbs.

secondary_outcome.measure: Determination of the relationship between diastasis and multiple dysfunctions of the pelvic floor muscles in postpartum women .
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Six weeks to up to 6 months after birth.
secondary_outcome.description: Occurrence of stress urinary incontinence over one week. Occurrence of several urinary leakages during the day, measured using the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire - Urinary Incontinence Short Form (ICIQ-UI Short Form).

secondary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of an overactive bladder over one week.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Six weeks to up to 6 months after birth.
secondary_outcome.description: Occurrence of several voidings and intensity of urgencies during 24 hours using the Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB - q)

secondary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of - cystocele, rectocele, and prolapse of the uterus.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Six weeks to up to 6 months after birth.
secondary_outcome.description: Occurrence of - cystocele, rectocele, and prolapse of the uterus by ultrasound and standard gynaecological examination. A validated questionnaire to assess the symptoms and quality of life of women with urogenital prolapse (P-Qol) was used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in incontinence quality of life using Urinary Incontinence Quality of Life Scale (I-QoL).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Six weeks to up to 6 months after birth.
secondary_outcome.description: The I-QoL is composed of three subscales (avoidance and limiting behaviour; psychosocial impact; social embarrassment) and comprises 22 questions with a total score in the range from 0 (worst quality of life) to 100 (best quality of life).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Six weeks to up to 6 months after birth.
secondary_outcome.description: Occurrence of low back pain using the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI).

intervention.description: IRD distance measured by a linear probe 2D usg. Occurrence of - cystocele, rectocele, and prolapse of the uterus by ultrasound and standard gynaecological examination.

study_pop.textblock: Women from six weeks to up to 6 months after birth, age over 18 years old.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women from six weeks to up to 6 months after birth, age over 18 years old.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Psychiatric illness, postpartum depression, non-cooperation. Neurological diseases conditions after a stroke, a history of brain injury, significant visual and hearing damage, confirmed by neurological examination. Serious internal, orthopedic and oncological diseases. Disagreement with inclusion in the study.

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics, Medical Faculty, PJ Safarik University, Kosice, Slovakia
